panels.description: This value counts the number of I/O requests that have been issued to the device driver but have not yet completed. It does not include I/O requests that are in the queue but not yet issued to the device driver
panels.title: IO Traffic (Bytes)

panels.description: This value counts the number of I/O requests that have been issued to the device driver but have not yet completed. It does not include I/O requests that are in the queue but not yet issued to the device driver
panels.title: Total IO Traffic (Bytes)

panels.description: This value counts the number of I/O requests that have been issued to the device driver but have not yet completed. It does not include I/O requests that are in the queue but not yet issued to the device driver
panels.title: IO Operations

panels.description: This value counts the number of I/O requests that have been issued to the device driver but have not yet completed. It does not include I/O requests that are in the queue but not yet issued to the device driver
panels.title: Total IO Traffic (Operations)

panels.description: This value counts the number of I/O requests that have been issued to the device driver but have not yet completed. It does not include I/O requests that are in the queue but not yet issued to the device driver
panels.title: IO Throughput (Write)

panels.description: This value counts the number of I/O requests that have been issued to the device driver but have not yet completed. It does not include I/O requests that are in the queue but not yet issued to the device driver
panels.title: IO Throughput (Read)

panels.description: I/O request size which is also referred as block size is the size of request that application uses to perform I/O operation on storage device. Every application uses a different I/O request size and based on how big the request size is, it can have pretty good impact on storage performance.

targets.expr: avg(rate(container_fs_writes_bytes_total{id="/", instance=~"$Instance", node=~"$Node", device=~"^(^$)|(overlay_.*)|(/dev/[sv]d[a-z][1-9]*)$"}[$__rate_interval])   / rate(container_fs_writes_total{id="/", instance=~"$Instance", node=~"$Node", device=~"^(^$)|(overlay_.*)|(/dev/[sv]d[a-z][1-9]*)$"}[$__rate_interval])) by (instance) != 0

panels.title: Estimated IO Request Size (Write)

panels.description: I/O request size which is also referred as block size is the size of request that application uses to perform I/O operation on storage device. Every application uses a different I/O request size and based on how big the request size is, it can have pretty good impact on storage performance.

targets.expr: avg(rate(container_fs_reads_bytes_total{id="/", instance=~"$Instance", node=~"$Node", device=~"^(^$)|(overlay_.*)|(/dev/[sv]d[a-z][1-9]*)$"}[$__rate_interval])   / rate(container_fs_reads_total{id="/", instance=~"$Instance", node=~"$Node", device=~"^(^$)|(overlay_.*)|(/dev/[sv]d[a-z][1-9]*)$"}[$__rate_interval]))  by (instance) != 0

panels.title: Estimated IO Request Size (Read)

panels.description:
read_time & write_time:
These values count the number of milliseconds that I/O requests have waited on this block device. If there are multiple I/O requests waiting, these values will increase at a rate greater than 1000/second; for example, if 60 read requests wait for an average of 30 ms, the read_time field will increase by 60*30 = 1800.
panels.title: Cummulative Time spent in IO (Write)

panels.description:
read_time & write_time:
These values count the number of milliseconds that I/O requests have waited on this block device. If there are multiple I/O requests waiting, these values will increase at a rate greater than 1000/second; for example, if 60 read requests wait for an average of 30 ms, the read_time field will increase by 60*30 = 1800.
panels.title: Cummulative Time spent in IO (Read)
